DOCNAME: CASE OF GUERRA AND OTHERS v. ITALY
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection rejected (non-exhaustion);Violation of Art. 8;Not necessary to examine Art. 2;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses - claim dismissed
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants all live in the town of GPE ) . QUANTITY away is the Enichem agricoltura company ’s chemical factory , which lies within the municipality of ORG .

CARDINAL . In DATE the factory , which produced fertilisers and caprolactam ( a chemical compound producing , by a process of polycondensation , a polyamide used in the manufacture of synthetic fibres such as nylon ) , was classified as “ high risk ” according to the criteria set out in Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ( “ ORG CARDINAL ” ) , which transposed into NORP law Directive CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EEC of ORG ( the “ Seveso ” directive ) on the major - accident hazards of certain industrial activities dangerous to the environment and the well - being of the local population .

CARDINAL . The applicants said that in the course of its production cycle the factory released large quantities of inflammable gas – a process which could have led to explosive chemical reactions , releasing highly toxic substances – and sulphur dioxide , nitric oxide , sodium , ammonia , metal hydrides , benzoic acid and above all , arsenic trioxide . These assertions have not been disputed by the Government .

CARDINAL . Accidents due to malfunctioning have already occurred in the past , the most serious CARDINAL on DATE when the scrubbing tower for the ammonia synthesis gases exploded , allowing several tonnes of potassium carbonate and bicarbonate solution , containing arsenic trioxide , to escape . CARDINAL people were admitted to hospital with acute arsenic poisoning .

CARDINAL . In a report of CARDINAL DATE a committee of technical experts appointed by ORG established that because of the factory ’s geographical position , emissions from it into the atmosphere were often channelled towards PERSON . It was noted in the report that the factory had refused to allow the committee to carry out an inspection and that the results of a study by the factory itself showed that the emission treatment equipment was inadequate and the environmental - impact assessment incomplete .

CARDINAL . In DATE the factory restricted its activity to the production of fertilisers , and it was accordingly still classified as a dangerous factory covered by ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL . In DATE ORG issued an order jointly with ORG prescribing measures to be taken by the factory to improve the safety of the ongoing fertiliser production , and of caprolactam production if that was resumed ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . In DATE the factory permanently stopped producing fertiliser . Only a thermoelectric power station and plant for the treatment of feed and waste water continued to operate .

CARDINAL . On DATE CARDINAL residents of PERSON ( including the applicants ) applied to ORG ( pretore ) complaining that the air had been polluted by emissions of unknown chemical composition and toxicity from the factory . Criminal proceedings were brought against CARDINAL directors of the impugned company for offences relating to pollution caused by emissions from the factory and to non - compliance with a number of environmental protection regulations .

Judgment was given on DATE . Most of the defendants escaped a prison sentence , either because the charges were covered by an amnesty or were time - barred , or because they had paid an immediate fine ( oblazione ) . CARDINAL directors were sentenced to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment and a fine of MONEY and ordered to pay damages to the civil parties , for having had waste dumps built without prior permission , contrary to the relevant provisions of ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL on waste disposal .

CARDINAL . On appeals by the CARDINAL directors who had been convicted and by ORG ( ORG ) and ORG , which had both joined the proceedings as civil parties claiming damages , ORG acquitted the directors on DATE on the ground that the offence had not been made out but upheld the remainder of the impugned decision . The court held that the errors which the directors were alleged to have made in the management of the waste were in fact attributable to delays and uncertainties in the adoption and interpretation , particularly by ORG , of regulations implementing ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL . Consequently , there was no damage that gave rise to a claim for compensation .
CARDINAL . A joint committee of representatives from the ORG and GPE was set up within ORG to implement the ORG directive .
The committee ordered a technical survey , which was carried out by a panel established by an order of the Minister for the Environment of DATE . The panel had the following remit :

( a ) to report on whether the factory conformed to environmental regulations as regards discharge of waste water , treatment of liquid and solid waste , emissions of gases , and noise pollution ; to report on safety aspects ; and to check what authorisations had been granted to the factory to those ends ;

( b ) to report on whether the factory site was compatible with its environment , having particular regard to the problems of protecting the health of the local population and the fauna and flora and of making appropriate use of the land ;
( c ) to suggest what action should be taken to obtain any missing data required to complete the reports under ( a ) and ( b ) above and to identify measures to be taken to protect the environment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the factory submitted the safety report required by LAW ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE the panel presented its report , which was sent to ORG . The latter published its conclusions on DATE and fixed CARDINAL DATE as the date on which the report required by LAW ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL on the risk of major accidents should be submitted to the Minister for ORG . It also recommended :

( a ) commissioning studies of the factory ’s safety and compatibility with its environment , additional analyses of disaster scenarios and of the preparation and implementation of emergency procedures ;

( b ) introducing a number of changes designed to reduce the atmospheric emissions drastically and to improve the treatment of waste water , making radical alterations to the production cycles for urea and nitrogen and carrying out studies on the pollution of the subsoil and on the hydrogeological structure of the factory site . These steps were to be taken within DATE . The panel also referred to the need to solve the problems of liquid combustion and the reuse of sodium salts .

The panel further called for a public industrial - pollution monitoring centre , to be set up by DATE , to carry out periodic checks on the factory ’s practices in relation to public health and environmental protection and to act as an epidemiological observatory .

CARDINAL . On DATE the problems relating to the operation of the factory were raised in a parliamentary question to the Minister for the Environment . On DATE , in ORG , a question on the same point was put to ORG . Replying to the latter question , the relevant Commissioner stated that ( CARDINAL ) Enichem had sent ORG the safety report requested pursuant to LAW ; ( CARDINAL ) on the basis of that report the Government had opened an investigation , as required by DATE ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL to check safety at the factory and , if appropriate , to identify any further safety measures needed ; and ( CARDINAL ) so far as the application of the ORG directive was concerned , the Government had taken the requisite measures with regard to the factory .

CARDINAL . Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL require the relevant mayor and prefect to inform local inhabitants of the hazards of the industrial activity concerned , the safety measures taken , the plans made for emergencies and the procedure to be followed in the event of an accident .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave its opinion on the emergency plan that had been drawn up by the prefect of GPE , in accordance with LAW of ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL . On DATE the plan was sent to the relevant committee of ORG . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE the under - secretary of ORG assured the prefect of GPE that the plan would be submitted promptly to ORG for its opinion and expressed the hope that it could be put into effect as quickly as possible , given the sensitive issues raised by planning for emergencies .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG and ORG jointly adopted conclusions on the factory ’s safety report of DATE , as required by LAW ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL . Those conclusions prescribed a number of improvements to be made to the installations , both in relation to fertiliser production and in the event of resumed caprolactam production ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and provided the prefect with instructions as to the emergency plan for which he was responsible and the measures required for informing the local population under LAW ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL .

In a letter of DATE to ORG , however , the mayor of ORG indicated that the investigation for the purpose of drawing up conclusions under LAW was still continuing and that he had not received any documents relating to them . He pointed out that ORG was still awaiting direction from ORG before deciding what safety measures should be taken and what procedures should be followed in the event of an accident and communicated to the public . He said that if the factory resumed production , the measures for informing the public would be taken as soon as the conclusions based on the investigation were available .

CARDINAL . As regards the obligation to inform the public on matters of environmental and public safety , LAW provides that any undertaking carrying on dangerous activities must submit a report to ORG and ORG giving details of , among other things , its activities , emergency procedures in the event of a major accident , the persons responsible for carrying these procedures out , and the measures taken by the undertaking to reduce the risks to the environment and public health . Article QUANTITY of ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL provides that anyone in charge of an undertaking who fails to submit the report required by LAW may be sentenced to up to DATE imprisonment .
CARDINAL . At the material time LAW of ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL provided that mayors were under a duty to inform the public of
( a ) the nature of the production process ;
( b ) the nature and quantities of the substances involved ;
( c ) the potential risks to employees and workers in the factory , members of the public and the environment ;
( d ) the conclusions on the safety reports submitted by the factory pursuant to LAW additional measures referred to in LAW ; and
( e ) the safety measures and procedures to be followed in the event of an accident .

LAW provided that , in order to protect industrial secrets , any person responsible for examining reports or information from the undertakings concerned was forbidden to disclose any information that he had thereby obtained .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provided that data and information on industrial activities obtained pursuant to ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL could be used only for the purposes for which they had been requested .

That provision was partly amended by Legislative Decree no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE . LAW of that decree provides for an exception to the ban on disclosure of industrial secrets in the case of certain information , namely that contained in an information sheet which the undertaking must complete and send to ORG and the regional or inter - regional technical committee . Mayors’ duties with regard to informing the public are unchanged and now appear in paragraph CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL also lays certain obligations on the prefect in the matter of providing information . In particular , paragraph CARDINAL of that provision ( now paragraph CARDINAL bis ) requires the prefect to draw up an emergency plan based on the information supplied by the factory and ORG . That plan must be sent to ORG and ORG . Paragraph CARDINAL goes on to provide that , after drawing up the emergency plan , the prefect must adequately inform the population concerned of the hazards of the activities , the safety measures taken to prevent a major accident , the emergency procedures planned for the area outside the factory should a major accident occur and the procedures to be followed in the event of an accident . The amendments made to LAW in the aforementioned legislative decree include a new paragraph CARDINAL , to the effect that ORG must establish reference criteria for emergency planning and the adoption of measures for the supply of information to the public by the prefect , and repeal of paragraph CARDINAL , which provided that the information referred to in paragraph CARDINAL had to be sent to ORG , ORG and the regional authorities concerned .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE , by which ORG was created and the first legal provisions on environmental damage introduced , provides that everyone has a right of access to the information on the state of the environment which is , in accordance with the law , available at the offices of the administrative authorities and may obtain a copy on defrayment of the authorities’ costs .

CARDINAL . In a judgment ( no . CARDINAL ) of CARDINAL DATE ORG ( Consiglio di PERSON amministrativa per la Regione siciliana DATE which in GPE replaces ORG ) held that the concept of “ information on the state of the environment ” included any information about human GPE physical surroundings and concerning matters of some interest to the community . On the basis of those criteria , ORG held that a district council was not justified in refusing to allow a private individual to obtain a copy of analyses of the fitness of water in the district in question for use as drinking water .

CARDINAL . Of particular relevance among the various ORG documents in the field under consideration in the present case is ORG DATE ) on the consequences of the GPE disaster , which was adopted on DATE ( at DATE Sitting ) . Referring not only to the risks associated with the production and use of nuclear energy in the civil sector but also to other matters , it states “ public access to clear and full information ... must be viewed as a basic human right ” .
